review.title: Building a comprehensive syntactic and semantic corpus of Chinese clinical texts
review.abstract: Objective: To build a comprehensive corpus covering syntactic and semantic annotations of Chinese clinical texts with corresponding annotation guidelines and methods as well as to develop tools trained on the annotated corpus, which supplies baselines for research on Chinese texts in the clinical domain. Materials and methods: An iterative annotation method was proposed to train annotators and to develop annotation guidelines. Then, by using annotation quality assurance measures, a comprehensive corpus was built, containing annotations of part-of-speech (POS) tags, syntactic tags, entities, assertions, and relations. Inter-annotator agreement (IAA) was calculated to evaluate the annotation quality and a Chinese clinical text processing and information extraction system (CCTPIES) was developed based on our annotated corpus. Results: The syntactic corpus consists of 138 Chinese clinical documents with 47,424 tokens and 2553 full parsing trees, while the semantic corpus includes 992 documents that annotated 39,511 entities with their assertions and 7695 relations. IAA evaluation shows that this comprehensive corpus is of good quality, and the system modules are effective. Discussion: The annotated corpus makes a considerable contribution to natural language processing (NLP) research into Chinese texts in the clinical domain. However, this corpus has a number of limitations. Some additional types of clinical text should be introduced to improve corpus coverage and active learning methods should be utilized to promote annotation efficiency. Conclusions: In this study, several annotation guidelines and an annotation method for Chinese clinical texts were proposed, and a comprehensive corpus with its NLP modules were constructed, providing a foundation for further study of applying NLP techniques to Chinese texts in the clinical domain.

metadata.title: Building a comprehensive syntactic and semantic corpus of Chinese clinical texts

sections.text: Aim: To build a comprehensive corpus covering syntactical and semantic annotations of Chinese clinical texts with appropriate annotation guidelines and methods, and to develop tools trained on the annotated corpus to provide the basis for clinical research into Chinese texts. Materials and Methods: An iterative annotation method was proposed to train annotation specialists and develop annotation policies. Subsequently, using annotation quality assurance measures, a comprehensive corpus was created containing annotations of parts-of-speech (POS) tags, syntactic tags, units, assertions and relationships. The Inter-Annotator Agreement (IAA) was calculated to evaluate the annotation quality, and a Chinese clinical word processing and information extraction system (CCTPIES) was developed based on our annotated corpus, syntactical annotation notes, assertions, assertions, and assertions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The situation is becoming increasingly urgent for China, a country with the largest population but limited medical resources. Faced with these challenges, the Chinese Ministry of Health has issued a series of relevant regulatory regulations since 2010 to standardize EMR systems and their intelligent support. With the rapid popularization of EMRs, the development of healthcare services has a solid data base. Clinical texts, an important type of patient data within EMRs, are free-text documents that contain large amounts of information about patients and their intelligent support.

sections.heading: 2. Background
sections.text: NLP tasks can be divided into low-level and higher-level tasks: low-level tasks include sentence boundary recognition, tokenization, word segmentation, part-of-speech (POS) tagging, shallow parsing, etc.; based on higher-level tasks, tasks include tasks called entity recognition (NLP), denial identification, relationship extraction, etc. [10] Commentary corpora in the clinical field are required as a bridge to adapt existing techniques to the clinical field. sections.heading: 2.1.1. Current status in English clinical texts
sections.text: The Mayo Clinic's cTAKES system aims at comprehensive processing of clinical texts and covers various NLP techniques [6]. In this work, a linguistic corpus for POS marking and shallow parsing was created by three linguistic experts, extending the Penn TreeBank (PTB) annotation guidelines [25, 26] to the clinical area. Furthermore, Albright et al. As Albright et al. sections.heading: 2.1.2. Current status in Chinese clinical texts
sections.text: Word segmentation is a first processing step for low-level tasks in Chinese texts. Xu et al. [13] found that vocabulary words and the elimination of ambiguities in clinical texts posed a major challenge to word segmentation, and that a state-of-the-art Chinese word segmentator trained by a general corpus would perform poorly in clinical terms. Therefore, they commented a corpus of segmented words manually in discharge summaries to improve the performance of word segmenters in Chinese clinical texts. Similarly, Zhang et al. [14] constructed similar corpus to achieve better word embedding characteristics.

sections.heading: 2.2. Annotated clinical text corpus for higher-level tasks
sections.text: In fact, this corpus was somewhat limited, as only medical problems and two types of claims were commented on. To automatically extract more information from clinical texts, Roberts et al. [16] randomly selected 50 clinical symptoms, 50 histopathological reports, and 50 imaging reports to annotated units, relationships, modifiers, co-references, and temporal information under the CLinical E-Science Framework (CLEF). This was the first corpus to expand the number of entity types to six, and was the first attempt to establish relationships with annotorial entities.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Current status in Chinese clinical texts
sections.text: Xu et al. [13] designated medical problems, treatments and tests in Chinese discharge guidelines and added two other entity types, namely drugs and anatomy. Drugs are separated from treatment to further analyze the use and efficacy of medications, and anatomy can help locate positions of symptoms or tests. Similar to Xu et al. "s corpus of entities, Lei et al. [19] developed an entity corpus of discharge summaries and admissions protocols of Beijing Union Medical College Hospital. Their entity categories differ from the 2010 i2b2 / VA concept guidelines in that treatments are divided into procedures and medications. In addition, Xu et al. [23] have commented medical terms on" the history of contemporary diseases "in clinical texts and proposed an effective rules-based method.

sections.heading: 2.3. Shortcomings of research on Chinese clinical texts
sections.text: Considering the level of research described above, research on clinical texts in China has three shortcomings: first, low-level research is quite limited, and this may result in a bottleneck in the performance of higher-level tasks; second, as far as we know, only negated claims and symptom-herbal correlations are to be commented on; other types of claims or relationships have not been systematically commented on; and third, policy tuning and annotator training in body creation are required, but descriptions of previous research efforts have not described these processing methods. Based on the above three points, and the fact that no clinical corpus written in Chinese has been made available to the public, it is imperative to create a comprehensive corpus that follows a complete annotation scheme.

sections.heading: 3.1. Types of clinical text
sections.text: Discharge summaries and progress notes used in this work were randomly selected from clinical texts of the Second Associated Hospital of Harbin Medical University (a general hospital in China), and all identifying information was removed manually to protect patient privacy. These two types of clinical text are semi-structured documents, and the free text in the document is divided into several sections as listed in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 3.2. Annotation guidelines
sections.text: Due to the diversity of clinical texts, there is no widely applicable annotation scheme in the clinical field [11]. Due to differences in language characteristics between Chinese and English, annotation guidelines for CTB [35-37] were selected to develop guidelines for subordinate tasks in Chinese clinical texts; in the meantime, annotation guidelines were used in the 2010 i2b2 / VA challenge [31-33] to develop guidelines for subordinate tasks. In accordance with the characteristics of Chinese clinical texts, we developed several modified annotation guidelines [38-41] for four subordinate and three superordinate tasks. Fig. 2 shows an example of the annotations in a sentence from the case characteristic part of a progress note.

sections.heading: 3.2.1.1. Word segmentation
sections.text: The segmentation guidelines for Penn Chinese TreeBank (CTB) [35] cannot cover all segmentation ambiguities in clinical texts, in particular the segmentation of medical terms, abbreviations and their combinations. To address these segmentation ambiguities, the word segmentation guidelines used three word properties: 1. Combinability [42], which means that a word can be divided into two sub-words and that each sub-word has its own POS; 2. Reduceability, which means that a word, if it is an abbreviation, can be converted back to its fully extended form to clarify its description; 3. Interchangeability, which means that a sub-word in a combination word can be replaced by another word with the same POS and that the new combination word can still occur in clinical texts. Obviously, medical terms, if they do not represent combinations, are such that these combinations are not typically found in the same method.

sections.text: Comments on parent tasks include 500 discharge summaries and 492 disease history records, including 39,511 units and 7,695 one-to-one relationships. Compared with discharge summaries, units and relationships contained in disease history records occur in larger quantities, accounting for three-fifths and four-fifths of the totals, respectively. Figure 6 shows distributions of the nature and nature of the relationships in these discharge and progress summaries. Treatment causes symptoms; TeRD, test reveals disease; TeRS, test reveals symptoms; TeAS, test is administered based on symptoms; SID, symptom indicates disease; DCS, disease causes symptoms.Discharge summaries and progress records have distributions of the four types of entities similar to those shown in Figure 6a. Symptoms account for nearly half of the total number of discharges, summaries and disease history records.

sections.heading: 4.4. System development
sections.text: To test the usefulness of our annotated corpus, we developed a Chinese Clinical Word Processing and Information Extraction System (CCTPIES) consisting of a word segmentator, POS tagger, shallow parser, full parser, entity recognition and relation extractor [49], and the performance of these modules was evaluated by 10-fold cross-validation of the annotated corpus; the results are shown in Table 5. We used a sequence marking method to train statistical models for word segmentation, POS tagging, shallow parsing and named entity recognition. CRF + + [50], an open source implementation of the conditional field algorithm, was used to train these models. As shown in Table 5, the evaluation results of these modules trained by CRF + + are quite excellent, as they all match the level of practical application achieved.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion

sections.heading: 5.1. Contributions of this work
sections.text: In this study, we constructed a comprehensive syntactic and semantic corpus of Chinese clinical texts that includes annotations on word segmentation, POS marking, shallow parsing, complete parsing, NOT, classification of assertions and extraction. As there is extensive medical knowledge in clinical texts, we referred to general and clinical annotation guidelines and developed annotation guidelines for Chinese clinical texts with the help of physicians. As described in the annotation development section, many improvements were proposed to adapt to the characteristics of Chinese clinical texts. Prior to the creation of the corpus, annotation guidelines maintained the formation of annotation guidelines until their annotation consistency remained at a relatively high level. During the annotation period, existing open source tools for pre-labeling were used and the burden on annotators was significantly reduced. As is well known, double annotation improves the quality of the corpus, as the correction of the corpus can be balanced with the cost of the correction of the corpus in terms.

sections.heading: 5.2. Limitations and future work
sections.text: Although our annotated corpus contributes to the study of Chinese texts in the clinical field, there are some limitations in our study. Due to limited annotation resources, the syntactic corpus covers only two departments within the Second Associated Hospital of Harbin Medical University. There are differences in the medical terminology of different hospital departments that may weaken the adaptability of some NLP techniques in different departments.Some research will be conducted in the future. First, transfer learning approaches will be introduced to solve the adjustment problem between different hospital departments. Second, some additional types of clinical texts should be commented on to improve the practicability of the NLP techniques developed based on this corpus. Third, active learning methods will be explored to reduce the annotation burden for annotators by filtering redundant samples from unlabeled data and selecting undertrained samples for the annotators. Finally, algorithms to improve the performance of NLP texts for clinical systems will be developed.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we described the structure of a corpus of Chinese clinical texts using an iterative annotation methodology, and by following the annotation guidelines developed in this study, a high degree of annotation consistency was achieved. In addition, a CCTPIES was developed to verify the usefulness of the corpus, which performed excellently. To the best of our knowledge, this corpus is the first comprehensive corpus of Chinese clinical texts to provide a solid basis for future research; the corresponding annotation resources can be found at http: / / github.com / WILAB-HIT / Resources.Author contritionsThis work was a collaboration of all authors. BH, JY, ZJ and CQ developed the annotation guidelines and participated in the construction of the corpus.BH, BD, YG and QY carried out body analyses. BH, ZJ and JC developed system modules and evaluated their performance. All authors contributed to the drafts of these were of interest in the evaluation.

Inter-annotator agreement (IAA) was calculated to evaluate the annotation quality and a Chinese clinical text processing and information extraction system (CCTPIES) was developed based on our annotated corpus. Results: The syntactic corpus consists of 138 Chinese clinical documents with 47,424 tokens and 2553 full parsing trees, while the semantic corpus includes 992 documents that annotated 39,511 entities with their assertions and 7695 relations. IAA evaluation shows that this comprehensive corpus is of good quality, and the system modules are effective. Discussion: The annotated corpus makes a considerable contribution to natural language processing (NLP) research into Chinese texts in the clinical domain. However, this corpus has a number of limitations. Some additional types of clinical text should be introduced to improve corpus coverage and active learning methods should be utilized to promote annotation efficiency. Conclusions: In this study, several annotation guidelines and an annotation method for Chinese clinical texts were proposed, and a comprehensive corpus with its NLP modules were constructed, providing a foundation for further study of applying NLP techniques to Chinese texts in the clinical domain.
